messages.message:
Can we track where the user came from through query string? If they came from ‘Explore’ take people back there, if they came from My Hub take back to that screen?

I see the button has a ‘Up one level’ so i’d want to go back to whatever I was doing before
@Siya I guess there could be, but from my own usage and what ive observed customers doing the button is used as ‘back’. I think any taking to a different location will lead to confusion.

We can make that option (5) where we have back and an arrow. We had previously agreed against this as we assumed users would use the browser back button to navigate back, but we can reopen it for consideration.

I'd love other feedback (tagging others that "+" this comment) @joshbronko @Matt Macnak @Tom Deaney @Tom @Aayush). Do you have a view on options 1-5 above on how we can modify this?

To me “Home” applies to the first place you are taken when you open up / login to an app.  I think not designing this way will create confusion with users (I was confused that the “Home” icon took me somewhere else other than the first screen that I opened when accessing AiHub).  To me, this is the home screen:
And this is the workspace view for converse (or whatever we want to call it):

I'd prefer option 2 `In all places we have "Home" with home icon which takes you to Explore` , or rather "takes you to Explore",  takes you to the home page / aihub.instabase.com (http://aihub.instabase.com)
Rationale: Same as Matt, it's just what "Home" means (the homepage)... so this is just to make the description of the link consistent with what it actually takes you

As for why not option 3 `In all places we have "My Hub" with home icon which takes you to My Hub` (this one also makes the link description consistent with where it goes), or making that a `Back` option that behaves the same as the browser back key -- in most website there's usually a button (usually on the upper left corner also) to let people get back to the homepage no matter how (not) useful the homepage is... for example you can click on the Google icon (screenshot) and goes back to the pretty useless Google home page (google.com (http://google.com)), but that's just what people are used to. If we think my hub is more useful, I'd suggest making my hub the home page instead for an login user. That can be a different discussion though -- right now going with option 2 seems like the best & most straightforward option for me.
